content.heading: 1. Description
content.paragraph: This document provides an overview of a bicycle, covering its history, components, and functionality.
content.heading: 2. History
content.paragraph: The bicycle has a rich history, evolving from early "velocipedes" to the modern machines we know today. Key milestones include:

list.item: Early 19th Century: Development of the "draisienne" or "velocipede," a human-powered vehicle without pedals.
1860s: Introduction of the "boneshaker," featuring pedals attached to the front wheel.
1870s: The "penny-farthing" emerged, with a large front wheel and a smaller rear wheel.
Late 19th Century: The "safety bicycle" with equal-sized wheels, a chain drive, and pneumatic tires became the standard.
20th & 21st Centuries: Continuous advancements in materials, design, and technology, leading to specialized bicycles for various purposes.

content.heading: 3. Components & Functionality
3.1 Frame & Basic Structure
content.paragraph: The bicycle frame provides the structural foundation. Common frame materials include steel, aluminum, carbon fiber, and titanium.
content.heading: 3.2 Wheels & Tires

list.item: Wheels: Consist of a hub, spokes, and a rim.
Tires: Provide cushioning and traction. Types include clincher, tubular, and tubeless.

content.heading: 3.3 Drivetrain
content.paragraph: The drivetrain transmits power from the pedals to the wheels. Key components include:

list.item: Pedals: Where the rider applies force.
Crank: Converts pedal motion into rotational force.
Chainrings: Gears attached to the crank.
Chain: Connects the chainrings to the rear cogs.
Cassette/Freewheel: Gears on the rear wheel.
Derailleurs (Front & Rear): Shift the chain between different gears.
Shifters: Control the derailleurs.

content.heading: 3.4 Braking System

list.item: Brake Levers: Activated by the rider.
Brake Calipers/Discs: Apply friction to slow or stop the wheels.
Brake Pads: Contact the rim or rotor to create friction.

content.heading: 3.5 Steering & Control

list.item: Handlebars: Used for steering and control.
Stem: Connects the handlebars to the steering tube.
Headset: Allows the steering tube to rotate smoothly.

content.heading: 3.6 Other Components

list.item: Seat/Saddle: Provides a comfortable seating surface.
Seatpost: Connects the seat to the frame.
Fork: Holds the front wheel and contributes to steering.
